In this study, the optimization of catalysts for the reverse water gas shift reaction by minimizing metal loading and enhancing the performance of supported Pt catalysts through Rh incorporation was done. The catalysts were synthesized by the wet impregnation method, in which the metal noble load in bimetallic samples decreased by approximately one-third compared to the reference platinum catalyst, with varying Rh-Pt ratios. In all materials, m-ZrO2, obtained by the hydrothermal method, was used as support. In the catalytic tests in a continuous packed-bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure, all samples were active to catalyze CO2 reduction between 200 and 300 °C. Bimetallic samples, particularly those with an Rh-Pt atomic ratio of 20–80, exhibited superior performance in the RWGS reaction despite their lower metal content. Based on the results of H 2 -TPR, FTIR in situ, and XPS, we propose that the enhanced CO production in bimetallic samples compared to Pt/ZrO2 catalysts can be attributed to Rh increasing the reduction extent of supported Pt. This enhancement facilitates the hydrogenation of bicarbonate species into formate species, which subsequently evolve into Pt0-CO and ultimately into CO. Additionally, Rh incorporation enables an alternative pathway for CO generation, where Pt0-carbonyls, known for their CO-producing capability, are formed via CO2 dissociation on the Pt0 surface. However, higher Rh concentrations favor the CO2 methanation rather than the RWGS reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords RWGS reaction Reaction mechanism Supported catalysts Bimetallic catalysts Rhodium Platinum ZrO2 In-situ FTIR Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide emissions from human activities have been associated as one of the main causes of global warming and climate change, triggering adverse effects such as losses and damage to nature and humanity [1]. To reduce its atmospheric concentration and thus avoid the increase in global temperature, it is necessary to limit its production and release, as well as the decrease of CO2 already present in the atmosphere. In that sense, several strategies have been studied, highlighting its conversion into added-value products since this approach not only reduces CO2 accumulation but could also bring considerable economic benefits in the future [2]. However, the high thermodynamic stability of CO2 limits its utilization as a raw material to few processes [3]. Hence, the use of catalysts represents a solution to this drawback [4]. The reverse water gas shift reaction (CO2+ H2 → CO + H2O, RWGS) mediated by catalysts has been one of the main methods studied for CO2 utilization since carbon monoxide can be produced, which can serve as a raw material for the synthesis of fuels and chemicals of industrial interest [5]. Through both experimental investigation and theoretical calculations, two possible mechanisms have been postulated to elucidate the catalytic pathways for the RWGS reaction [5–7]: the redox (carbonyl) pathway and the associative (formate) pathway, which could occur on metals supported on reducible and non-reducible metal oxides, respectively. In the redox mechanism, CO2 undergoes direct dissociation to generate carbonyl species, subsequently desorbing as carbon monoxide (CO). Concurrently, the generated Oads species on the catalyst surface, responsible for surface oxidation, react with H2 to produce H2O. For its part, in the associative mechanism, the CO2 dissociation is mediated by H atoms. Hence, species derived from CO2 adsorption, such as (bi)carbonate and formate, are decomposed to CO and H2O. In general, the catalysis of RWGS requires materials with high hydrogenation activity and mild CO dissociation ability (to break only one CO bond). Several metals (such as Au, Pt, Pd, Ni, Cu, Co, and Fe) supported on different metal oxides (Al2O3, TiO2, CeO2, ZrO2, etc.) have been used to catalyze successfully the RWGS reaction [7]. However, noble metals, such as Pt and Pd, still attract attention because they have high selectivity towards carbon monoxide and since they can operate below 300 °C (at atmospheric pressure) [8,9], avoiding the coke deposition and metal sintering as in the case of other transition metals where the catalysis happens at higher temperatures (≥ 400 °C) [10]. Several key factors that influence the catalytic performance of the RWGS reaction have been addressed lately, such as CO2 and H2 activation, and the role of support, among others. For example. Chen, X. et al. [11] studied the CO2 activation on Pt/CeO2 catalysts. Their results suggest that the oxygen sites on the support play a crucial role in activating CO₂. However, other authors [12] have indicated that surface defects, such as oxygen vacancies, increase catalytic activity. Another important factor in catalytic design is the size of the platinum sites. Some authors argue that atomic dispersion of Pt improves catalytic activity by promoting hydrogen spillover, as demonstrated by Kang, X et al. [13], which generates more oxygen vacancies near Pt sites and facilitates CO production. However, recent work by da Silva Sousa et al. [14] revealed that Pt nanoparticles are effective catalysts for the RWGS reaction at low temperatures, whereas higher temperatures suppress their activity and favor CO formation on isolated Pt species. The supported platinum materials have several advantages for catalyzing the RWGS reaction compared to other metals, but their high cost limits their use. Therefore, decreasing the noble metal load is a work in continuous development to generate catalysts more cost-effectively. Although the decrement in the metal load in supported Pt catalysts increases the specific activity (due to highly dispersed metal sites), it also decreases the RWGS reaction rate (due to a lesser amount of metal atoms) [11–13]. In that sense, it is necessary to reduce the noble metal load in the catalysts without losing the CO production reaction rate. It is well-known that bare platinum can activate H2 while CO2 is weakly adsorbed on its surface, leading to a limited activation of this compound [9]. Hence, the appropriate selection of support may enhance CO2 adsorption. Some metal oxides, such as ZrO2 (specifically the monoclinic crystalline phase), can activate CO2 since it has O-2 sites of high basicity and a surface rich in hydroxyl groups [14–17]. Also, the incorporation of a mildly oxophilic promotor, such as rhodium, can help the C–O breaking, which could increase the RWGS reaction activity [18–20]. Based on the insights described above, this study aims to reduce the noble metal content in ZrO2-supported Pt samples by enhancing the catalytic activity of the Reverse Water Gas Shift reaction through Rh incorporation. Bimetallic Rh-Pt samples supported on m-ZrO2, with a total metallic load one-third lower than the Pt/m-ZrO2 reference material, were synthesized accordingly. These catalysts were evaluated in a packed-bed continuous flow reactor for the RWGS reaction and compared with monometallic Pt samples. Characterization of the catalysts under reaction conditions was performed using FTIR to identify the surface species crucial to the catalytic process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts The support (ZrO2) was synthesized using the hydrothermal method. In the process, 5.55 g of ZrO(NO3)2 (Sigma Aldrich) and 7.21 g of CO(NH2)2 (Sigma Aldrich) were dissolved in 80 mL of deionized water. The solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (200 mL), which was maintained at 120 °C for 20 h. After the thermal treatment, it was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The resulting precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water. The solid obtained was dried at 120 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. The catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method using H2PtCl6 (Sigma Aldrich) and RhCl3 (Sigma Aldrich) as precursors. During the procedure, the support (ZrO2) was put in contact with an aqueous solution of the precursors. Subsequently, the solvent was removed under constant stirring at 80 °C. The obtained material was dried at 120 °C and calcined at 450 °C for 5 h. The theoretical metal loading in the monometallic Pt catalysts was 60 µmol of metal/gram of catalysts, while in the bimetallic samples, this value was reduced by one-third (40 µmol of metals/gram). In bimetallic samples, the Rh-Pt atomic ratio was varied systematically. The labeling and the actual metal loading in the samples are shown in Table 1 . 2.2 Catalysts characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were done in a PANalytical Aeris diffractometer equipped with a Pixel 1D detector and Cu Kα (λ = 1.5405 Å) as the radiation source, at 40 kV and 15 mA, with a step size of 0.021 °/min, from 20 to 65° (2θ). N2 physisorption (−196 °C) analysis was performed in a Micrometrics Tristar 3000 to obtain the textural properties. Before the studies, the samples were treated in a vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. The platinum and rhodium contents were quantified using an ICP-OES Perkin Elmer Optima 3300DV instrument. Before the measuring, 12 mg of each sample was treated with 2 ml of aqua regia and 1 ml of HCl overnight. Then, the mixture was diluted to 50 ml with deionized water. A calibration curve was made using Inorganic Ventures® 100 ppm Precious Metals ICP standard compound. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) studies of the samples were carried out using ChemBET Pulsar equipment from Quantachrome Instruments. Before the TPR characterization, the samples were treated at 120 °C in a He flow (100 mL/min) for 1 hour. TPR measurements were performed using 100 mL/min of an H2/N2 mixture (5 % H2 vol/vol) from room temperature up to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Transmission electron micrographs were taken with a JEOL JEM-2100F (STEM) microscope equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) operating at 200 kV and 54 μA. For the characterization, the reduced samples (treated with 30 mL/ min of H2 at 300 °C for 1 h) were dispersed in isopropanol using an ultrasonic bath. Then, the obtained suspension was placed in a cooper grid. The solvent was evaporated at room temperature. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic tests were done in a continuous packed bed flow reactor (inner diameter=0.3 cm) coupled to an online Shimadzu 12-A chromatograph with a TCD, using 5A and Porapack Q as columns. For the measurements, 100 mg of each sample (particle diameter= 37 µm) was placed in the reactor, where they were treated with 30 mL/min of H2 at 300 °C for 1 hour before the experiments. Then, the gas flow was switched to 12.5 mL of the reactive mixture (20 % vol/vol CO2 and 80 % vol/vol H2). The gas hourly space velocity was fixed at 10,350 h-1 for the studies. The CO2 conversion (XCO2 ) and selectivity towards CH4/CO products (SCH4 and SCO ) under steady-state conditions from 200 °C to 300 °C, were used to evaluate the catalytic activity. These were calculated according to the Eqs. (1–3), respectively: (1) X C O 2 ( % ) = F C O 2 i n − F C O 2 o u t F C O 2 i n × 100 (2) S C H 4 ( % ) = F C H 4 o u t F C O 2 i n − F C O 2 o u t × 100 (3) S C O ( % ) = F C O o u t F C O 2 i n − F C O 2 o u t × 100 Where Fi is the inlet or outlet molar flow of component i (mol s-1). To investigate if mass transfer limitations exist in our catalytic system axial dispersion criterion was determined from the modified Mears equation, as outlined in Eq. (4) [21]. (4) L B d p > 8 · n Pe ln ( 100 100 − X C O 2 ) Where L B represents the bed length of the (m), d p denotes the particle diameter (m), n is the reaction order, and P e indicates the Peclet number, which can be calculated as follows (Eq. 5) [22]: (5) Pe = u · d p D Where u and D denote the linear velocity of the flow (m s-1) and the Diffusion coefficient of the gases (m2/s), respectively. Calculated value on the left side of Eq. (4) LB/dp was 162, while that the value obtained calculated for the right side was 120 at the maximum CO2 conversion observed and taking the global reaction order as 1 [23]. Hence, the problems associated with the axial dispersion can be negligible. To assess whether external diffusion restricts catalysis, Mears criterion was employed as described in Eq. (6) [22] (6) M e = − r ′ A ρ b R n k c C A b In this equation, − r ′ A is the maximum observed reaction rate (kmol/kgcat-s), ρ b is the bulk density of the catalyst (kg/m3), R is the radius of the catalytic particle (m), k c is the mass transfer coefficient (m s-1) and C A b is the bulk reactants concentration (mol/dm3). The Me value obtained from our conditions was 2.27 × 10–7. This value is lower than 0.15. Hence, the effects of external mass transfer can be ignored [22]. Thiele modulus (φ) was also calculated, and its value was 5 × 10–3. In consequence, the effectiveness factor (η) tends to 1. Therefore, it is possible to rule out internal mass diffusion effects [22]. 2.4 FTIR characterization under reaction conditions The characterization by FTIR spectroscopy under reaction conditions was executed in an Agilent 660 spectrophotometer, with an ISRI transmission cell/flow reactor with ZnSe windows. Self-supporting wafers of the catalysts with a thickness of 60 mg/cm2 were prepared by pressing the powdered samples at a pressure of 10 × 103 kg/cm2. The self-supporting wafers were treated with a 50 mL/min reducing mixture (25 % H2/75 % N2 vol/vol) at 300 °C for 1 hour before the CO2 hydrogenation experiments. Then, they were cooled down to 125 °C. For the CO2 hydrogenation experiments, the reduced samples were exposed to 50 mL/min of the reaction mixture (12 % CO2/ 48 % H2/ 40 % N2 vol/vol) while the temperature of the FTIR cell/flow reactor was increased up to 300 °C. Simultaneously, IR spectra were recorded with a resolution of ±4 cm-1. 2.5 XPS characterization X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained using a SPECS® spectrometer equipped with a PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer featuring sub-degree angular resolution (< 0.5°). The instrument utilized XR 50 Al-X-ray and μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray monochromator sources for Al excitation lines. Charge-related effects were mitigated by calibrating the C 1 s peak binding energies of adventitious carbon to 284.5 eV Before the measurements, the samples were pressed with 10 × 103 kg/cm2 to obtain wafers with a thickness of 60 mg/cm2. The wafers were loaded in the FTIR cell/flow reactor, where they were reduced as described in Section 2.4. The reduced catalysts were transferred to the equipment using a glove box filled with N2 to avoid reoxidation. Once in the equipment, the samples were treated with 0.5 bar of carbon dioxide in a high-pressure chamber at 125 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization According to the results obtained by ICP-OES detailed in Table 1, the monometallic sample had a platinum load of 60 µmol/gcat. The metal contents in bimetallic samples were 42, 38, and 43 µmol/gcat, whose actual Rh-Pt atomic ratios were near 10–90, 20–80, and 30–70, respectively (Table 1). Therefore, the total decrease in the noble metal load ranged between 28.3 and 36.7 % compared to the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst. The results obtained from X-ray diffraction characterization are presented in Fig. 1 . The diffraction patterns of the catalysts and the support (ZrO2) correspond to characteristic peaks of the zirconia monoclinic phase (JCPDS No 01–0750). These results concur with those of Li et al. [24], who obtained m-ZrO2 through a hydrothermal method under similar conditions. Fig. 1 also shows no diffraction planes of rhodium and platinum in the XRD patterns of the catalysts, which suggests the well-dispersion of both metals on their surface. The textural properties of the materials obtained from the isotherms of N2 adsorption-desorption at −196 °C (Figure S1) are shown in Table 1. In general, the surface area of all catalysts maintained similar values between 35.8 and 37.6 m2/g. Regarding the pore volume (0.07–0.09 cm3/g) and diameter (8.3–9.9 nm), all samples exhibited comparable values due to the low load of supported metal (Table 1) and their well-dispersion, according to XRD results (Fig. 1). 3.2 H2-TPR characterization To understand how the incorporation of Rh and the decrease of metal load affect the reducibility of the catalyst, the samples were subjected to H2-TPR characterization in the temperature range between 50 and 600 °C (Fig. 2 ). In the TPR profile of the 60Rh 0 Pt 100 sample, the peak that emerged at 241 °C (β peak) can be attributed to the reduction of Pt4+to Pt0 species [25]. In turn, the peak at 378 °C (γ peak) may be associated with the reduction of zirconia at the metal-support interface [26,27]. In the bimetallic-supported samples, a combination of two peaks between 100 and 300 °C was obtained (Fig. 2). The peaks centered around 121–135 °C (α peaks) might correspond to the reduction of Rh2O3 [21,22], while the peaks at 206–233 °C (β peaks) might attributed to the reduction of Pt oxide species to Pt0 [28]. Additionally, in the Rh/Pt-containing samples, an intense and broad peak above 300 °C emerged (γ peaks), which can be attributed to the partial surface reduction of zirconium oxide [26,27]. The analysis of the H2-TPR curves is shown in Table 2 . As described above, the peaks of H2 consumption below 300 °C can be due to the reduction of the supported metals in the form of Rh2O3 (peak α) and PtO2 (peak β). In turn, the peak above this temperature can be attributed to the partial reduction of the ZrO2 surface (peak γ), promoted by the H atoms formed in the metallic sites (Rh0 and Pt0) via H2 dissociation. Based on the area of the peaks of H2 consumption (< 300 °C, Fig. 2) and the actual load (quantified by ICP-OES, Table 2), the extent of metal reduction was calculated using chemical Eqs. (7) and (8). In the 60Rh 0 Pt 100 sample, the primary H2 consumption occurred below 300 °C (80.7 µmol/g). Hence, the extent of the reduction of platinum in this sample corresponds to approximately 67.6 %. Table 2 shows that the bimetallic catalysts have a higher metal percentage reduction than the ZrO2-supported Pt sample. Possibly, the H2 dissociation promoted by Rh0 sites (generated by the Rh2O3 reduction at lower temperatures) can explain it. It is important to highlight that the 40Rh 20 Pt 80 sample exceeded the stoichiometric reduction extent (115.3 %). Therefore, it is possible that a portion of H atoms migrate from metal sites to the ZrO2 surface. As observed in Fig. 2, the molecular hydrogen that reacts with the sample over 300 °C increases with the Rh incorporation. For example, the consumption of H2 in the 40Rh 30 Pt 70 sample (147.6 µmol/g, Table 2) was more than three times higher than the ZrO2-supported Pt catalyst (46.8 µmol/g, Table 2). These data demonstrate that rhodium improves the surface reduction of the support (ZrO2), possibly by the reaction between the H atoms on Rh sites and surface O-2 species via spillover. These results coincide with those obtained by Verkama and coworkers [29], who also observed a higher partial surface reduction of the support in Rh/ZrO2 than Pt/ZrO2 during the H2-TPR characterization. The metal-support interaction (MSI) and hydrogen spillover on supported metal catalysts keep an inverse relation, i.e., the increase in MSI causes a decrease in the spillover effect [30]. Therefore, the higher hydrogen spillover in the bimetallic samples (which increases in function of Rh load) can be explained by the lower metal-support interaction in Rh-ZrO2 than Pt-ZrO2, evidenced by the inferior reduction temperature of Rh species than Pt (Fig. 2). (7) P t O 2 + 2 H 2 → P t 0 + 2 H 2 O (8) R h 2 O 3 + 3 H 2 → R h 0 + 3 H 2 O 3.3 Catalytic tests To evaluate the effect of the rhodium over the catalysis RWGS reaction developed by ZrO2-supported Pt, the monometallic and bimetallic materials were tested as catalysts in a continuous packed-bed flow reactor. The results obtained under steady conditions are shown in Fig. 3 . According to the catalytic tests, the monometallic sample (60Rh0Pt100 ) was active to catalyze the CO2 conversion from 225 °C, generating carbon monoxide as the main product with a minor proportion of methane at high temperatures (SCH4=1 %, Fig. 3). These results agree with Chen X. et al. [31] and Seuser G. et al. [32], who observed CO production in supported-Pt catalysts at similar temperatures at atmospheric pressure from CO2 and H2. The catalytic tests shown in Fig. 3 also provide evidence that the presence of Rh in Pt/ZrO2 catalysts significantly improves the CO2 conversion in the complete interval of examined temperatures (200 to 300 °C). Demonstrating that the addition of Rh on the Pt/ZrO2 surface increases the activation and transformation of carbon dioxide, even with a lower load of Pt, possibly due to the higher extent of metal reduction in bimetallic samples (Table 2). However, high Rh loads and elevated temperatures tend to form methane instead of carbon monoxide, as in the case of the 40Rh 30 Pt 70 sample. Fig. 4 shows that the reaction rate of CO production (via RWGS) is higher in the Rh-Pt samples than in the monometallic Pt sample, even with a lower metal content. This effect is highlighted at low temperatures, especially in the samples of 40Rh20Pt80 and 40Rh30Pt70 . Since at 200 °C were the only ones able to catalyze the CO formation, also at 225 °C, they had an increase of 220 % and 350 % RWGS reaction rate, respectively, compared with the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst. Nevertheless, unlike the other bimetallic materials, the 40Rh 30 Pt 70 sample shows a decrease in the rate of CO production above 250 °C (Fig. 4), possibly because the methane formation is favored by the increase in the temperature and Rh ratio since the rhodium is active to hydrogenate the CO2 until methane, as we have reported in our previous works [33–35]. From the data of the catalytic tests (Fig. 4), the activation energies (Ea) for the catalysis of CO production by RWGS reaction were calculated (Fig. 5 ). For the case of the reference material (60Rh0Pt100 ), the Ea resulted in 60 kJ/mol, which is similar to values obtained by other authors in samples of platinum supported on SiO2(67.9 kJ/mol) [36], SiC (61.6 kJ/mol) [37], CeO2 (67.8 kJ/mol) [38]. While in the bimetallic samples, the activation energies decreased to 48, 42, and 20 kJ/mol for 40Rh 10 Pt 90 , 40Rh 10 Pt 90 , and 40Rh 30 Pt 70 (only until 250 °C), respectively (Fig. 5). The data were plotted as a function of the rhodium content in each sample, revealing a linear correlation between the decrease in activation energy (Ea) and the increase in the Rh/Pt atomic ratio (Fig. 5 inset). This indicates the promoter effect of rhodium on the ZrO₂-supported Pt catalysts in the RWGS reaction, at least under the conditions used in this study. 3.4 FTIR characterization during CO2 hydrogenation To understand how rhodium promotes carbon monoxide production from CO2 and H2 over ZrO2-supported Pt, the surface species formed under reaction conditions were characterized by FTIR spectroscopy in situ. 3.4.1 FTIR measurements during CO2 over bare ZrO2 support The details of the CO2 activation on the support (ZrO2, previously treated with H2 at 300 °C as the catalysts) were obtained by FTIR characterization at increasing temperature (Fig. 6 ). When the reactive mixture (12 % CO2/ 48 % H2/ 40 % N2 vol/vol) entered the FTIR cell/flow reactor and was in contact with the ZrO2 surface at 125 °C, several bands appeared in the IR spectra, as shown in Fig. 6. The intense bands at 1630, 1428, and 1224 cm-1 have been observed in carbon dioxide adsorption studies, where they have been assigned to υa(CO3), υs(CO3), and δ(CH) vibration modes of bicarbonate species bonded on ZrO2 [15,32,39]. These species can be formed by the nucleophilic attack of the oxygen atom of the basic surface hydroxyl groups to gaseous CO2 [14,40,41]. A shoulder at 1705 cm-1 was also observed, which can be attributed to carbonate species linked to two Zr+4 sites (υa(CO3), bridged carbonate) [36,37]. Additionally, a band at 1330 cm-1 emerged, which can be attributed to (υs(CO3)) of carbonate species in bidentate configuration (b-carbonate) [15,32,39]. The formation of carbonate species on metal oxides has been attributed to the result of the interaction of CO2 with the surface basic oxygen ions [42]. However, the origin of bidentate carbonate species could be due to the reaction between CO2 and the surface oxygen vacancies [14,38]. The temperature increase caused FTIR spectra changes, as shown in Fig. 6. The bands of bicarbonate (1630, 1428, and 1224 cm-1) and bridged carbonate (1705 cm-1) species decreased gradually in the function of the temperature; however, they still even at 300 °C. For its part, the band at 1330 cm-1 associated with bidentate carbonate species remained approximately constant during the test. The band reinforced the existence of these species on the surface of ZrO2 at 1555 cm-1 assigned to (υa(CO3)) of b-carbonate [15,32,39], which got more resolved with temperature increase, indicating their higher thermal stability than others derived from CO2 adsorption on ZrO2 in this experiment (Fig. 6). No bands of methane or carbon monoxide were observed, demonstrating that platinum or rhodium are necessary to catalyze the CO2 hydrogenation successfully. 3.4.2 FTIR measurements during CO2 on 60Rh0Pt100 catalysts The ZrO2-supported Pt sample (60Rh0Pt100 ) was characterized using FTIR under the conditions of the RWGS reaction to determine the surface species involved in the catalysis. The IR spectra taken during the flow of the reactive mixture while the temperature increased (Fig. 7 ) were quite different from those obtained with the bare ZrO2 (Fig. 6). At 125 °C, two intense bands, and one broad shoulder appeared at 2077, 2056, and 1991 cm-1, assigned to the CO stretching (υCO) of carbonyl species linearly bonded to Pt0 sites, respectively. According to the literature, the frequency of these bands could be related to the Pt coordination number [43–45]. Specifically, the band at 2077 cm-1 can be attributed to COads on Pt0 aggregates or small nanoparticles, while that located at 2056 cm-1 could be related to carbonyl species on Pt° clusters, and the shoulder at 1991 cm-1 can be assigned to COads on isolated metallic platinum sites. As observed in Fig. 7, the intensity of the Pt0-CO bands decreases as follows: clusters<nanoparticles<isolated atoms. In the spectra recorded at 125 °C, bands of (bi)carbonate species on the support were not detected (Fig. 7); instead, IR signals of formate species emerged at 1570 (υa(CO2)), 1383 (δ(CH)), and 1364 cm-1(υs(CO2)). This suggests that the platinum sites catalyze the transformation of CO2-derived species to formate species, possibly by a route where the H atoms (obtained by H2 dissociation on Pt0) react with (bi)carbonate species, as other authors have proposed [42,46]. The presence of Pt0-CO and formate species on ZrO2 suggests that both the metal and the support participate as CO2 adsorption sites (Fig. 7). However, the origin of Pt0-CO species in CO2 hydrogenation reactions catalyzed on supported catalysts is still under debate. Some proposals indicate that the formation of carbonyl species on platinum sites is due to CO2 dissociation (on Pt0). Other authors have mentioned that the formate species on ZrO2 can be dehydroxylated near metallic sites to produce Pt0-CO and Zr-OH [47–49]. With the temperature increase, the corresponding bands of platinum carbonyls (2077, 2056, and 1991 cm-1) and formate species (1570, 1383, and 1364 cm-1) reached their maximum intensities at approximately 150 °C (Fig. 7). Above this temperature, the IR signals of both species decreased (Pt0-CO and formate) concomitantly with the temperature increase. Simultaneously, a couple of bands at 2174 and 2120 cm-1 emerged and increased their intensities along the experiment, both are characteristic of carbon monoxide gas [50] The temperature of the rise of the bands of carbon monoxide during the FTIR characterization matches with the CO production observed in the catalytic tests in a continuous flow reactor (Fig. 4). Based on these observations (Fig. 6), it is possible to assume that the carbonyls on Pt0 and formate species can participate actively in the catalysis of the RWGS reaction. As the decrease of the formate bands was more intense than Pt0-CO (Fig. 6), it is assumed that the formation of CO probably proceeds mainly from formate species. During the experiment, a band at 1445 cm-1, assigned to carbonate species on zirconium oxide [51,52], arose and increased its intensity with the temperature. This behavior suggests that these species accumulate on the surface of ZrO2 and do not participate in the catalysis. 3.4.3 FTIR measurements during CO2 on 40Rh20Pt80 catalysts According to the catalytic tests shown in Figs. 4 and 5, the 40Rh 20 Pt 80 sample displayed higher CO production above 250 °C, even with a lower metal loading than the monometallic catalyst (Table 2). Hence, to gain details on how the Rh incorporation to Pt/ZrO2 catalysts increases the activity of the RWGS reaction, in situ FTIR characterization was done (Fig. 8 ). Similar bands to those observed in the 60Rh 0 Pt 100 sample emerged after the contact of the reactive mixture with the surface of the 40Rh20Pt80 catalyst at 125 °C (Fig. 8). The bands at 1572, 1385, and 1361 cm-1 can be attributed to bidentate formate species on zirconium oxide (υa(CO2), δ(CH), and υs(CO2), respectively) [53], whose origin can be due to the reduction of (bi)carbonate species by H atoms generated on Pt0 and Rh0 sites via H2 dissociation. Fig. 8 shows the formation of platinum carbonyl species from CO2 and H2, as in the case of the monometallic catalyst (60Rh0Pt100 , Fig. 7), since bands at 2074, 2053, and 1988 cm-1 assigned to carbonyl species bonded to Pt0 sites (υCO) with different coordination numbers of platinum [43–45]., i.e., nanoparticles, clusters, and isolated atoms, respectively, were detected in the FTIR spectrum. It is noteworthy that, unlike the 60Rh 0 Pt 100 sample at 125 °C, the band related to CO on the Pt° clusters (2053 cm-1) has a similar intensity to that on nanoparticles (Fig. 8). The intensity of the bands related to carbonyl species on Pt0 is lower than monometallic samples; possibly, this is due to the lower load of platinum (Table 2). As mentioned above, the formation of Pt0-CO could be due to the dissociation of carbon dioxide on Pt0 sites or by the dehydroxylation of formate species (derived from the reduction of bicarbonate species, formed by the CO2 adsorption on ZrO2). No bands of CO on Rh0 were observed, probably because they overlap with the platinum carbonyl bands. With the temperature increase, the bands of formate species (1572, 1385, and 1361 cm-1) and Pt0-CO (2074, 2053, and 1988 cm-1) increased until they reached their maximum value between 150 and 175 °C (Fig. 8). Above these temperatures, their intensities began to decrease. In parallel, in the CO stretching region, two new bands at 2174 and 2120 cm-1 appeared and increased in function of the temperature; both are attributed to carbon monoxide in phase gas. This behavior is like the one observed in the monometallic sample (Fig. 7); therefore, it is possible to deduce (again) that carbonyls on Pt0 sites and formate species are involved in carbon monoxide production. Nevertheless, a sharper decrease of the formate bands was observed than Pt0-CO, which could suggest that CO formation comes mainly from formate species. Above 275 °C, a weak band at 1303 cm-1 emerged, whose assignation can be due to δ(CH) vibration mode of gas-phase methane [54]. The apparition of this band coincides with the temperature of methane formation in the catalytic tests (Fig. 4). The formation of methane in bimetallic catalysts, especially at high temperatures, could be due to that Rh atoms catalyze the CO2 methanation. A band at 1445 cm-1 assigned to carbonate species emerged and increased along the FTIR characterization (Fig. 8), like the monometallic catalyst, which suggests that these species were accumulated on the surface of ZrO2. 3.5 XPS characterization of the reduced and after CO2 adsorption To assess the effect of Rh incorporation on the oxidation states of platinum in Pt/ZrO2 catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on both reduced and CO2-treated (at 125 °C) 60Rh 0 Pt 100 and 40Rh 20 Pt 80 samples (Fig. 9 ). Deconvolution of the Pt 4f spectra identified two surface platinum species with binding energies (B.E.) for Pt 4f7/2 ranging from 71.0 to 71.4 eV, corresponding to metallic Pt, and from 72.3 to 72.6 eV, corresponding to Pt2⁺ species [46,55,56]. In both species, the Pt 4f7/2–4f5/2 splitting was 3.33 eV. The specific binding energies of 4f7/2 and their relative abundances are detailed in Table 3 . In the reduced samples, the proportion of Pt0 species was higher in the bimetallic 40Rh 20 Pt 80 catalyst compared to the monometallic Pt/ZrO2 (60Rh0Pt100 ) sample (Table 3). These findings are consistent with the H2-TPR results (Fig. 2), which show a greater extent of reduction in the 40Rh 20 Pt 80 catalyst than in the monometallic Pt/ZrO2 sample (Table 2). This suggests that the incorporation of Rh promotes the reduction of oxidized Pt species. After treatment with carbon dioxide at 125 °C, XPS spectra revealed minimal changes in the electronic state of platinum in the monometallic sample (60Rh0Pt100 , Fig. 9), with the proportion of Pt0 varying by approximately 2 % between the reduced and CO2-treated samples (Table 3). In contrast, the Pt sites in the bimetallic sample underwent significant modification, as the abundance of Pt0 species decreased from 69 % to 57 % due to oxidation during CO2 adsorption (Table 3). However, the proportion of metallic Pt species in the 40Rh 20 Pt 80 sample remained higher than that in Pt/ZrO2 even after CO2 treatment. This is significant because these metallic sites facilitate H2 activation. The oxidation of Pt following CO2 exposure may result from the dissociation of CO2, potentially assisted by hydrogen (2Pt0 + CO2 → Pt0-CO + Pt2⁺-OH) [57]. Hence, based on these observations, it is possible to assume that the carbonyl species on the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst (determined by FTIR spectroscopy, see Section 3.4) are formed by the dehydroxylation of formate species (Pt0 + Zr+4-COOH →Pt0-CO + Zr+4-OH). Meanwhile, in bimetallic samples, the CO2 dissociation on the Pt0 surface, assisted by hydrogen, can also happen. The XPS data also displayed that according to the Pt/Zr ratio, the platinum is more dispersed in the bimetallic samples due to the lower metal content (Table 3). 3.6 Plausible mechanism of RWGS reaction on bimetallic Rh-Pt supported on ZrO2 In this work, we optimized catalysts for the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction by minimizing metal loading and enhancing the performance of Pt/ZrO2 catalysts through the incorporation of Rh. Catalytic tests conducted in a continuous packed-bed flow reactor demonstrated that incorporating Rh into ZrO2-supported Pt catalysts enhances CO2 hydrogenation at temperatures ranging from 200 to 300 °C under atmospheric pressure (Fig. 4). Our results also revealed that in the bimetallic samples, CO generation is increased, as evidenced by a higher RWGS reaction rate compared to the monometallic Pt catalyst (60Rh 0 Pt 100 ) (Fig. 5), despite a lower metal loading. Notably, a linear correlation was observed between the increase in the Rh/Pt ratio and the decrease in the RWGS reaction activation energy (Fig. 5 inset), suggesting a promoter effect of Rh. However, as detailed in Fig. 4, high temperatures and elevated Rh/Pt ratios favor CH4 formation over CO production due to the high selectivity of Rh towards methane. Hence, in situ FTIR characterization was performed to elucidate how Rh enhances the RWGS reaction on Pt/ZrO2 catalysts. Under reaction conditions, the IR spectra of the monometallic catalyst (60Rh0Pt100 ) displayed bands corresponding to Pt0-carbonyls and bidentate formate species (on ZrO2) upon introduction of the reactive mixture at 125 °C (Fig. 7). As the temperature increased, the intensities of these bands diminished concurrently with the production of carbon monoxide, indicating that both species may participate in the catalytic process. Similarly, in situ FTIR characterization of the bimetallic 40Rh 20 Pt 80 sample revealed bands corresponding to Pt0-CO and formate species on ZrO2, exhibiting behavior nearly identical to that of the ZrO2-supported Pt catalyst (Fig. 8). Thus, both Pt0-CO and formate species can be regarded as intermediates in the Reverse Water Gas Shift (RWGS) reaction. However, formate consumption was more pronounced than Pt0-CO in both samples, suggesting that carbon monoxide production is primarily derived from surface formate species. Two main pathways have been proposed for the Reverse Water Gas Shift (RWGS) reaction catalyzed by supported catalysts: the carbonyl pathway and the formate pathway [58]. In the carbonyl mechanism, CO2 is reduced on the supported metal sites, forming adsorbed carbon monoxide (COads) and adsorbed oxygen (Oads) species. The COads can desorb as carbon monoxide, while hydrogen adatoms (Hads), generated from H2 dissociation on the metal surface, react with Oads to form hydroxide (OHads), and subsequently water [59]. In the formate mechanism route, carbon monoxide is produced from the decomposition of formate species formed on the support. These formate species arise from the reduction of CO2-derived adsorbed species [60]. To determine whether this pathway occurs in our samples, formate species were deliberately introduced onto the surface of ZrO2 through formic acid adsorption [61]. Then they were heated under an H2 flow while IR spectra were recorded (Figure S2). The results revealed the formation of bidentate formate species, similar to those generated under CO2 hydrogenation conditions (Figure S2). As the temperature increased, the intensity of these bands decreased slightly, likely due to thermal desorption, as no CO gas bands were detected in the IR spectra (Figure S2). This suggests that the decomposition of formate species to carbon monoxide is not favorable on the bare ZrO2 surface. Therefore, the reduction of surface formate species during the reaction conditions could be attributed to their conversion to Pt0-carbonyls via dehydroxylation when in proximity to metallic sites, which can subsequently transform into Pt0 and CO. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis revealed that CO₂ adsorption at 125 °C affects only the oxidation state of the 2 % Pt0 species in the reduced monometallic catalyst. Consequently, the formation of carbonyl species in this sample is primarily attributed to the dehydroxylation of formate species (Pt0 + Zr4⁺-COOH → Pt0-CO + Zr4⁺-OH). In contrast, the 40Rh 20 Pt 80 sample exhibited greater oxidation of Pt0 to Pt2⁺ compared to the 60Rh0Pt100 catalyst. This observation suggests that surface carbonyls can also form on Pt⁰ sites through CO2 dissociation, potentially assisted by hydrogen (2Pt0 + CO2 → Pt0-CO + Pt2⁺-OH). This pathway is likely more energetically favorable than direct dissociation [57]. Consequently, this additional mechanism may explain the increased carbon monoxide production observed in bimetallic catalysts. Conversely, the direct dissociation of CO2 on surface-exposed metallic rhodium species cannot be dismissed, as suggested by [62]. The analysis of the IR data shows that the maximum number of formate species (as the intensity of the υa(CO2)=1575 cm-1 band, at 200 °C) per mmol of metal (Pt+Rh) increased with the Rh/Pt atomic ratio, as detailed in Fig. 10 . A similar tendency between the increment in Rh/Pt atomic ratio and the CO2 conversion is observed in Fig. 3. Therefore, from this information, it is possible to assume that the increase in Rh sites promotes the hydrogenation of bicarbonate species into formate species since the H2 spillover is enhanced in bimetallic samples according to H2-TPR characterization results (Table 2). After the reduction stage, a higher intensity of the bands of hydroxyl groups at 3725, 3642, and 3480 cm-1, attributed to υ(OH) of type I (linear), II (bidentate), and III (tridentate) hydroxyl groups bonded to ZrO2, respectively [63–65] was observed in bimetallic samples in comparison with Pt/ZrO2 catalyst (Figure S3). Several investigations have observed an increment in the surface OH concentration in supported metal catalysts after the H2 treatments, attributing to the H2 spillover effect from the metal to the support [66–68]. Therefore, it is possible to assume that the addition of Rh to Pt/ZrO2 catalysts enhances the H2 spillover, as was evidenced by the H2-TPR results described above. It is likely that formate species on ZrO2 near Pt sites are converted into Pt0-CO and subsequently desorbed as carbon monoxide. However, when these species are in proximity to Rh sites, they undergo complete hydrogenation to CH4. Therefore, an increase in the atomic Rh/Pt ratio would shift the selectivity toward methane rather than CO, as observed in the catalytic tests with the 40Rh 30 Pt 70 sample (Fig. 3). The 40Rh 20 Pt 80 sample was characterized by transmission electron microscopy coupled with EDX elemental mapping to obtain more information about its surface atomic distribution (Fig. 11 ). As expected, zirconium (blue dots) and oxygen (white dots) atoms are evenly distributed across the material. Both supported metals, Pt and Rh, are well-dispersed on the catalyst surface. However, while platinum atoms (green dots) tend to form clusters and small nanoparticles, rhodium atoms (red dots) appear to remain isolated, likely due to their low loading. Based on our data, the increased CO production observed in the bimetallic samples, compared to the Pt/ZrO2 catalysts, can be attributed to the role of Rh in enhancing the reduction of supported Pt. This improvement promotes the hydrogenation of bicarbonate species into formate species, which are subsequently converted into Pt0-CO and ultimately into carbon monoxide. Additionally, introducing Rh enables an alternative pathway for CO production, where Pt0-carbonyls, known to generate CO, are formed via CO2 dissociation on the Pt0 surface. Based on these findings, we have demonstrated how Rh incorporation enhances catalytic activity in the RWGS reaction (Fig. 12 ). Initially, carbon dioxide interacts with hydroxyl groups on the zirconium oxide surface, resulting in the formation of bicarbonate species (labeled as species IA in Fig. 12). Simultaneously, hydrogen molecules dissociate on Rh0 and Pt0 sites, producing hydrogen adatoms. These adatoms migrate via spillover and promote the conversion of adsorbed CO2-derived species (bicarbonate) on the support into bidentate formate species (species IIA, Fig. 12). As the species approach Pt sites, they undergo dehydroxylation, forming carbonyls bound to Pt0 sites (species IB, Fig. 12), while regenerating hydroxyl groups. These carbonyl species can then desorb from Pt0 as carbon monoxide. Additionally, an alternative pathway for CO formation involves the dissociation of carbon dioxide on Pt0 sites, potentially assisted hydrogen, resulting in adsorbed CO (COads, species IB, Fig. 12) which then can be desorbed as carbon monoxide gas. 4 Conclusions This study focused on optimizing catalysts for the reverse water gas shift reaction by minimizing metal loading and enhancing the performance of Pt/ZrO2 catalysts through Rh incorporation. The catalysts were synthesized by the wet impregnation method, in which the metal noble load in bimetallic samples decreased by approximately one-third in comparison to the reference platinum catalysts, varying the Rh-Pt proportion. In all materials, m-ZrO2, obtained by the hydrothermal method, was used as support. The catalytic tests performed in a continuous packed-bed flow reactor showed that all samples were active to catalyze the CO2 reduction under atmospheric pressure between 200 and 300 °C. Notably, superior performance for the catalysis of the RWGS reaction was observed in bimetallic samples, even with a lower metal amount, remarkably in the material in which the Rh-Pt atomic ratio is 20–80. According to our findings, the higher CO production in bimetallic samples compared to Pt/ZrO2 catalysts can be attributed to Rh increasing the reduction extent of supported Pt. This improvement promotes the hydrogenation of bicarbonate species into formate species, which then evolve into Pt0-CO and ultimately into carbon monoxide. Moreover, the incorporation of Rh facilitates an alternative pathway for CO generation, where Pt0-carbonyls (known to produce CO) is formed via CO2 dissociation (possibly assisted by hydrogen) on the Pt0 surface. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the optimization of catalysts for the reverse water gas shift reaction by minimizing metal loading and enhancing the performance of supported Pt catalysts through Rh incorporation was done. The catalysts were synthesized by the wet impregnation method, in which the metal noble load in bimetallic samples decreased by approximately one-third compared to the reference platinum catalyst, with varying Rh-Pt ratios. In all materials, m-ZrO2, obtained by the hydrothermal method, was used as support. In the catalytic tests in a continuous packed-bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure, all samples were active to catalyze CO2 reduction between 200 and 300 °C. Bimetallic samples, particularly those with an Rh-Pt atomic ratio of 20–80, exhibited superior performance in the RWGS reaction despite their lower metal content. Based on the results of H 2 -TPR, FTIR in situ, and XPS, we propose that the enhanced CO production in bimetallic samples compared to Pt/ZrO2 catalysts can be attributed to Rh increasing the reduction extent of supported Pt. This enhancement facilitates the hydrogenation of bicarbonate species into formate species, which subsequently evolve into Pt0-CO and ultimately into CO. Additionally, Rh incorporation enables an alternative pathway for CO generation, where Pt0-carbonyls, known for their CO-producing capability, are formed via CO2 dissociation on the Pt0 surface. However, higher Rh concentrations favor the CO2 methanation rather than the RWGS reaction.

coredata.dc:title: Optimizing reverse water gas shift catalysis: Minimizing metal loading and enhancing performance with Pt/ZrO2 catalysts through Rh incorporation
